body: Thanks!  Hmm...from the screenshots above, it sort of looks like a button you should press.  Maybe removing the border would help with that?

> Thanks! Hmm...from the screenshots above, it sort of looks like a button you should press. Maybe removing the border would help with that?

Technically it is a button you can press, the callback is just None. And, Yes removing the border helps but it would need a clean refactor to move the button more to the right.

I think idle/busy are substantially different from interrupt and restart (and everything else in the notification area), and warrant an _always on_ indicator somewhere, probably outside the notification area. What does pauses indicate? It looks like it is setting a breakpoint or something.
@minrk: +1.  I think of idle/busy as a status light sort of indicator (except very muted to not draw attention to itself unnecessarily).

Agree that the current icon are not perfect. You can shop among accessible icons with [FA v3](http://fontawesome.io/3.2.1/icons/) and tell me what is your preference. I'll update that to have to not have borders..
FA v3 appears to have `icon-circle` and `icon-circle-blank`, which I think would do the job nicely. I agree that it should be always on and have no border.

Ha ! I missed those, I've seen them in v4 but not in v3, thanks !. 

So let say, 
- Running `icon-circle`(full)
- Iddle `icon-circle-blank`
- restarting `icon-refresh` "rotating" arrows
- interrupting `icon-remove-circle` (cicle + cross inside)

Am I missing something ? Does it suit you ?

![capture decran 2014-01-21 a 22 33 37](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/335567/1968533/76e78386-82e4-11e3-8974-b6ea2a20fb38.png)

Look like that. Only 2 issues I see, restart icon is not clear. Interrupt and restart stay indefinitively until smth is executed. (no Idle event is emitted after Restart or Interupt.

Can you try to just have this indicator respond to busy/idle?

On Tue, Jan 21, 2014 at 1:40 PM, Matthias Bussonnier <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> [image: capture decran 2014-01-21 a 22 33 37]https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/335567/1968533/76e78386-82e4-11e3-8974-b6ea2a20fb38.png
> 
> Look like that. Only 2 issues I see, restart icon is not clear. Interrupt
> and restart stay indefinitively until smth is executed. (no Idle event is
> emitted after Restart or Interupt.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/4842#issuecomment-32966664
> .

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com
Done.

I agree with just having this indicator show busy/idle, but I think this leaves no UI feedback when you interrupt the kernel (which I currently do accidentally by hitting `i` in command mode). I might leave the text notification we had before for interrupting. It's specifically busy/idle that is conceptually a state, not an event.
Tests are failing...

- I love the visual look of this indicator. Fantastic!
- The kernel restart and interrupt events should still fire the regular notification area.
Ahh, one other thing. When the notebook page is loaded, we should fire an idle event by hand to cause the indicator to appear. Right now on page load, it is missing until you run something.

We should ensure that the indicator appears on load, but I'm not sure that
firing a kernel idle event is the right way to do it.

> Right now on page load, it is missing until you run something.

and

> We should ensure that the indicator appears on load, but I'm not sure that
> firing a kernel idle event is the right way to do it.

Well IMHO that should be fixed by triggering a first Idle event the first time the kernel is idle on start. 
that would fix all the issues. 

Also I don't get why all my PRs are failling, even github tell me on submit that they cannot be merged. Which for all is not true.

OK, I tested and I really like the visual effect...

> Well IMHO that should be fixed by triggering a first Idle event the first time the kernel is idle on start. 
> that would fix all the issues.

I agree...

> Well IMHO that should be fixed by triggering a first Idle event the first time the kernel is idle on start. 
> that would fix all the issues.

No it wouldn't, because it would only work on the first page load that starts the kernel, not for any refresh of the page after that.

Ahh, good point, we should figure out a different way of handling the
initial state then.

On Sat, Jan 25, 2014 at 10:47 AM, Min RK notifications@github.com wrote:

> Well IMHO that should be fixed by triggering a first Idle event the first
> time the kernel is idle on start.
> that would fix all the issues.
> 
> No it wouldn't, because it would only work on the first page load that
> starts the kernel, not for any refresh of the page after that.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/4842#issuecomment-33296492
> .

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

> No it wouldn't, because it would only work on the first page load that starts the kernel, not for any refresh of the page after that.

You are right... I missed the refresh thing... thanks for noticing...

It would be great to get this merged for 2.0. But we need to decide how to handle the initial state:
- Leave as is - it won't appear until the kernel sends a status message.
- Just guess as idle - wrong if reopening a notebook with a busy kernel.

We should also remember that we will be soon moving to a model where the kernel won't be running when a page is loaded always. So maybe it is best to leave the current behavior?
I would suggest a circle with question mark, or alike. I'll try to rebase and do that soon.

I'm -0.5 on adding another possibility for the symbol as @Carreau suggests - it's more visual complexity, but it doesn't really convey any useful information to the user.

At present, the notebook always starts its own kernel, right? So for now, why don't we show the indicator as idle to start with, and work out what to do about attaching to an existing kernel when that is a possibility?

I agree with @takluyver on not introducing another icon for the ? state. Yes, the notebook always starts with a kernel now. I am fine with @takluyver suggestion about triggering idle upon load, even though it will make a mistake sometimes.

I thought I already wrote this, but I guess not. A logical initial state would be:
- start busy
- send kernel_info
- set idle on reply

I can't think of any cases where this will get the wrong answer, possibly excepting kernel_info not implemented by the kernel.

I think that the following could happen.

Kernel is doing heavy work:
- send kernel_info
- send long execute request
- kernel_info commes back trigger idle but kernel is still busy.
@Carreau - no, a busy message will be sent when the execute request starts, so the kernel will be marked as busy.

The decision at the dev meeting today as to have @Carreau rebase and then merge with the current functionality. At page load, the indicator will just not be shown, which is fine for now. Once we do the work for issue #4938 we can rethink all of this...
rebased.
This seems to have more JS test failures than usual. Were we relying on the notification messages for some of the tests?
